body: Still Making Deals At a Different Table Years back, Theodore W. Kheel helped settle so many big and bitter labor disputes in New York and around the country that he was widely regarded as the maestro of mediation. These days, he still uses his talent for bringing people together, though for ends other than soothing passions at the bargaining table.
title: FOLLOWING UP

title: Once Just a Cupcake, These Days a Swell

body: To the Editor: Re ''Remains of the Day'' (Oct. 12), on the changes in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn: I am growing weary of articles on neighborhood gentrification that speak from the purely nostalgic viewpoint of the ''middle-class pioneers.'' body: JUSTIN MOORE, a 27-year-old transplant from Florida who came to New York nearly three years ago, talks about his goals as if he has already achieved them. All he has ever wanted to be is a rock star, and he may have what it takes. Slinky and lean, with silky dark hair and a mysterious scar on his left cheek, he radiates charm and a certain bad-boy
title: The Two Worlds Of Justin Moore

title: FOOD STUFF; Sure They're Cans, but They Have Class

title: Remains Of the Day

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bedford-Stuyvesant; Brownstones by the Tree-Lined Block

title: URBAN TACTICS; Ashes to Ashes, All Over Town

body: TODAY is not the anniversary. It is just one of the 364 other days of the year on which this city remembers. title: About New York; Remembering What a City Can't Forget

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Detective Suspended Over Escape

body: Steak in Washington On Saturday, Charlie Palmer is opening a new restaurant, Charlie Palmer Steak, in Washington at 101 Constitution Avenue. title: AT DINNER WITH: Nell Campbell and Matilda Roche; A Diva Enters, With Marabou And Mashed Potatoes

title: RITUALS; True Luxury? A Car in Manhattan

title: Steinbeck as Remedy For Gum Plague
